Award.AbstractNarration:
A working group of the Southern California Earthquake Center (SCEC) will develop and deploy cyberinfrastructure for mining seismic wavefields through data intensive computing techniques in order to extend similarity search for earthquake detection to massive data sets. Similarity search has been used to understand the mechanics of tectonic tremor, transform our understanding of the depth dependence of faulting, illuminate diffusion within aftershock seismicity, and reveal new insights into induced earthquakes. These results were achieved with modest data volumes ? from ~ 10 seismic stations spanning ~ 10 km ? yet they increased the number of detected earthquakes by a factor of 10 to 100. This geoinformatics project will develop the cyberinfrastructure required to enable high-sensitivity studies of earthquake processes through the discovery of previously undetected seismic events within massive data volumes.

This goal of this project is to develop a cyberinfrastructure to mine seismic waveform data. The effort will develop methods and hardware to use coherent signal processing on very large waveform databases to detect, locate and characterize events that cannot be detected by standard network operations (detection of single arrivals, association, location by optimization).

The methodology involves the use of a network-based approach for earthquake detection, especially weak and unusual events that in the current method of treating signals individually go unreported. The PIs will work on the large T and the large N problem, where large T is using waveform similarity of multiple events over time to detect earthquakes over long periods of time; and the large N is using waveform similarity of single events over space as recorded on a dense seismic array with up to thousands of stations.

The results will greatly increase knowledge of the number of seismic sources of various kinds and potentially identify patterns in earthquake occurrence that could inform hazard and near-term rupture forecasting. Seismicity induced by human activities is an emerging problem that adversely affects energy options for the 21st century, including shale gas development, enhanced geothermal energy, and carbon sequestration. A more complete view of seismicity related to these activities is essential to managing the risks they pose.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided support to develop and implement techniques for mining seismic waveforms for sources not detected by standard methods. This involved the following major research activities along with various sub-tasks: (1) Performing a theoretical parameter study on limits to detection of small seismic events in different velocity structures and distances, to provide improved guidelines for network design and reported detections not consistent with propagation of seismic information (and hence likely false). (2) Using small aftershocks in the San Jacinto fault zone, CA, to detect additional smaller aftershocks, and analyzing the spatial distribution and frequency-magnitude statistics of the events in relation to fault zone structure and mechanics. (3) Using small aftershocks in the Yuha Desert, CA, to detect additional smaller aftershocks, and analyzing the results in relation to post-mainshock aseismic slip and fluid diffusion processes. (4) Developing techniques to produce new templates not associated with earthquakes already included in seismic catalogs. (5) Detecting and quantifying signatures of air-traffic (airplanes, helicopters) events in continuous seismic waveforms. (6) Performing analysis of non-diffuse characteristics of the ambient seismic noise field to clarify the existence of various sources that modify aspects of the noise. (7) Developing improved IT platform for mining seismic waveforms and archiving the obtained results.

The studies provided three PhD students and three postdoctoral fellows with state-of-the-art techniques for extracting high-resolution information from continuous seismic waveforms recorded by dense seismic arrays and regional stations. The research provided also some experience with field work, led to collection of seismic and meteorological data sets, eight publications in prime peer-reviewed journals, one additional paper in review and multiple conference presentations. The benefits to the participants extend beyond technical scientific learning and will hopefully have long lasting positive effects on their careers.
